sec.title: Abstract
sec.p:
Three genera of Anostraca have been recorded so far in Senegal : StreptocephalusBaird, 1852 , BranchinellaSayce, 1903 and ArtemiaLeach, 1819 . The occurrence of the previously recorded freshwater species in Senegal have been confirmed in this work, namely Streptocephalus zeltneri Daday, 1910
, S. sudanicus Daday, 1910
and Branchinella ( Branchinellites ) chudeaui (Daday, 1910)
. New records and the description of a new species are given. The new species, Streptocephalus wolof sp. nov. , has been recognized through molecular (mitochondrial and nuclear markers) and morphological (egg shape) data. The adult stage of this new species is morphologically indistinguishable to its closely related species Streptocephalus zeltneri , suggesting the existence of two cryptic species in Senegal . Finally, some taxonomic comments on the genus Streptocephalus are presented.
Key words: Africa, cryptic species, fairy shrimp, integrative taxonomy, phylogeny

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
During recent field surveys of temporary ponds in Western Africa, several populations of Anostraca were studied. In this work we characterize the diversity of fairy shrimps in Senegal by using morphological and molecular characters in order (1) to identify and confirm the species diversity present in the country, and (2) to depict the phylogeographic patterns of the species of the genus Streptocephalus across different ecoregions in Senegal . Molecular and morphological analyses revealed the existence of a new species morphologically similar and sister to S. zeltneri , which is described and named herein as Streptocephalus wolof sp. nov .
This work is a step forward on the knowledge of the Streptocephalus diversity in sub-Saharan Africa. The existence of cryptic diversity unveiled through integrative taxonomy constitutes a new challenge that is already being considered in current studies of Anostraca .

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Phylogenetic analyses. Cytochrome c oxidase I and ITS2 fragments were sequenced for 38 specimens ( Table 1 ). The phylogenetic trees resulted from the nuclear and mitochondrial datasets were totally congruent between each other when separately analyzed. Therefore, phylogenetic analyses of Streptocephalus were subsequently performed by using the combined dataset of both genes. The combined alignment was composed by 1537 base pairs. Translated coxI sequences lacked stops codons.

The Bayesian analysis (
) shows high support in most of the clades (PP= 1). The species of Streptocephalus from Senegal were recovered in two main and non-closely related clades, one is constituted by two reciprocally monophyletic lineages represented by S. zeltneri and the undescribed taxon, while the other included S. sudanicus , S. torvicornis and S. mackini .

The analyzed species are deeply divergent from each other with distances ranging from 10 to 21% for coxI and 3 to 34% for ITS2 . Intraspecific genetic distances range from 0.3 to 1% and from 0.4 to 5% for coxI and ITS2 , respectively ( Table 3 ).

( Daday 1910a ; Hartland-Rowe 1969 ;
Hamer et al. 1994b

Maeda-Martínez et al . (1995b)
included S. zeltneri in a species group formed by S. bouvieri , S. gauthieri , S. rothschildi and S. spinifer . (1995b)
.

). This trait was consistent in the revised populations of S . zeltneri with mature females (two out of the three populations).
